Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Stellar structure on Core-collapse Supernovae and their Ejecta

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Core-collapse supernovae (CCSN) are direct probes of stellar evolution and the dominant producers of heavy elements. Significant advancement in our understanding of the CCSN mechanism has occurred in the last decade, highlighted by the understanding that the CCSN problem involves the complex interaction of many physical inputs that can only be fully considered in three-dimensional (3D) simulations. The number of 3D simulations, which include sufficient realistic physics, that have been completed is still small and the simulations are generally under-resolved. Recent observational surveys have greatly increased the number of well observed CCSN and identified many of the pre-supernova stars, establishing a more direct relationship between the characteristics and the details of the explosion.

This project will survey the range of the stellar mass of CCSN progenitors using the state-of-the-art CCSN code Chimera on the Blue Waters system to understand how the variations in pre-supernova structure affect the explosive outcomes. The simulations will begin from progenitor stars that span the range of stellar masses from the lightest to heaviest stars that might explode. The progenitor star models will be from the first generation of stars formed from the primordial gas of the Big Bang as there exists a class of second-generation stars contaminated by only the ejecta of first-generation supernovae that offer a unique opportunity to measure the ejected products of individual CCSN. This choice offers an important contrast to prior studies which have focused on metal-rich stars. The project will compute five 3D simulations over the course of 2 years with 1-degree resolution. This surpasses the resolution of any current self-consistent, full-physics CCSN simulation.

The broader impacts of the project include the engagement of local and visiting students (graduate and undergraduate) and post-docs, providing training in both astrophysics and high-performance computing that our students and post-docs carry with them to later jobs in academia and industry. The project will also make frequent public lectures on supernova-related topics to enhance public understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Massive stars (at least 8 solar masses) explode when their iron cores collapse to a dense neutron star (NS) and release the gravitational binding energy change of that collapse to heat the material above the NS that drives a shock through the rest of the star and creates an observable supernova.

This project computed well resolved, physically detailed, multidimensional models of core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe) with our Chimera supernova code on the BlueWaters supercomputer to better understand how these explosions are impacted by the structure of the star's inner core at collapse by modeling stars with different initial masses and compositions to obtain variations the internal structure. The first figure shows a slice through the developing explosion for one of our 3D models illustrating its complex structure.

We computed five 3D models through the revival of the shock, with three of those extending far enough to show the development of the explosion. For these the developing explosion energy grows very differently [Fig. 2]. One of the models staturates the explosion energy quickly at a low value, while the other two take longer to explode, but develop larger explosions following the pattern seen in their 2D (axisymmetric) counterparts. The pattern in the explosion energy is matched by the neutrino heating rate [Fig. 3] where there are large differences in the heating rate driving the explosion. This is correlated with the neutrino fluxes (not shown) and with the growth and mass of the NS [Fig. 4], where we see the strongest heating and explosions for the most massive NS.

We also computed a dozen 2D models, varying only the initial mass, and they showed a similar correlation in the explosion energy, heating rate, neutrino fluxes, and NS masses to the 3D models. The growth of the NS mass is connected to the  structure of the star before collapse -- the mass of the iron core and the densities and thicknesses of the shells that immediately surround it.

We have also computed several 2D models to understand the impact of the nuclear equation of state (EoS; the relationship between the pressure, temperature and other properties of the dense, nuclear matter in the central NS) which is not fully determined from nuclear physics inputs. These models [Fig. 5] show the modern EoSs to be relativly similar with the more traditionally used EoS of our 3D models being a relative outlier, This points to the need to use a more modern EoS in any future runs (2D or 3D).

Outside our immediate interest in the nature of the CCSN explosion mechanism and its variety the data generated by this project will be used to understand the gravitational wave and neutrino signals from CCSNe in the hope of a nearby (and detectable) event and the elements and isotopes made in the explosions.These analysis are already underway using the data we have archived from these runs. During the course of this work, two postdoctoral researchers and two doctoral students performed computations and analyses and the generated data was used by a half dozen undergraduate and high school summer interns to develop and use new analysis tools.


Last Modified: 03/24/2020
Modified by: Eric J Lentz

Images (1 of )
  • Slice through a 3D model of an exploding 15 solar mass star shown in entropy. Heated plumes (red/orange) rise from the NS (circular center) between accretion streams (light blue) bringing material down from outside (dark blue) the shock and drive the explosion.
    Lentz et al, in prep
    Eric J Lentz
    Exploding 15 solar mass star
  • For 3D explosion models, the neutrino heating rate for 15 (black), 25 (red), and 9.6 (green; 2D dashed) solar mass progenitors.After similar initial 50 ms, the weakest (9.6) and strongest (25) heating correspond to growth of explosion energy.
    Lentz et al, in prep
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Eric J Lentz
    Neutrino heating rate
  • For 3D explosion models, the mass of the proto-NS for 15 (black), 25 (red), and 9.6 (green; 2D dashed) solar mass progenitors.The largest (9.6 model) and smallest (25 model) NS masses correspond to heating rate and growth of explosion energy.
    Lentz et al, in prep
    Eric J Lentz
    Growth of proto-neutron star
  • For most complete explosion models, the estimated explosion energy of supernovae from 15 (black), 25 (red), and 9.6 (green; 2D dashed) solar mass progenitors computed in 3D.
    Lentz et al, in prep
    Eric J Lentz
    3D Explosion energy
  • 2D models showing variation in nuclear equation of state (EoS). The magenta line is for the "traditional" EoS used in many models, including our 3D models, while the other lines represent a selection of modern EoSs tabulated using modern nuclear physics constraints.
    Landfield et al., in prep.
    Eric J Lentz
    Explosion energy of 2D models
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Massive stars (at least 8 solar masses) explode when their iron cores collapse to a dense neutron star (NS) and release the gravitational binding energy change of that collapse to heat the material above the NS that drives a shock through the rest of the star and creates an observable supernova. This project computed well resolved, physically detailed, multidimensional models of core-collapse supernovae (CCSNe) with our Chimera supernova code on the BlueWaters supercomputer to better understand how these explosions are impacted by the structure of the star's inner core at collapse by modeling stars with different initial masses and compositions to obtain variations the internal structure. The first figure shows a slice through the developing explosion for one of our 3D models illustrating its complex structure. We computed five 3D models through the revival of the shock, with three of those extending far enough to show the development of the explosion. For these the developing explosion energy grows very differently [Fig. 2]. One of the models staturates the explosion energy quickly at a low value, while the other two take longer to explode, but develop larger explosions following the pattern seen in their 2D (axisymmetric) counterparts. The pattern in the explosion energy is matched by the neutrino heating rate [Fig. 3] where there are large differences in the heating rate driving the explosion. This is correlated with the neutrino fluxes (not shown) and with the growth and mass of the NS [Fig. 4], where we see the strongest heating and explosions for the most massive NS. We also computed a dozen 2D models, varying only the initial mass, and they showed a similar correlation in the explosion energy, heating rate, neutrino fluxes, and NS masses to the 3D models. The growth of the NS mass is connected to the structure of the star before collapse -- the mass of the iron core and the densities and thicknesses of the shells that immediately surround it. We have also computed several 2D models to understand the impact of the nuclear equation of state (EoS; the relationship between the pressure, temperature and other properties of the dense, nuclear matter in the central NS) which is not fully determined from nuclear physics inputs. These models [Fig. 5] show the modern EoSs to be relativly similar with the more traditionally used EoS of our 3D models being a relative outlier, This points to the need to use a more modern EoS in any future runs (2D or 3D). Outside our immediate interest in the nature of the CCSN explosion mechanism and its variety the data generated by this project will be used to understand the gravitational wave and neutrino signals from CCSNe in the hope of a nearby (and detectable) event and the elements and isotopes made in the explosions.These analysis are already underway using the data we have archived from these runs. During the course of this work, two postdoctoral researchers and two doctoral students performed computations and analyses and the generated data was used by a half dozen undergraduate and high school summer interns to develop and use new analysis tools.
